Course Home

Functionalism

This week we are considering the view that what it is to have a mind is to be able to perform sufficiently complex computations. On this view, minds are merely very complex computers. To introduce you to the topic, please have a conversation with this program.

Reading

  • Required
    • Textbook, ch.5, pp. 129–138, 156–159
    • ‘Computing Machinery and Intelligence’, A.M.Turing
  • Optional
    • Philosophy and the creation of computers
    • ‘Troubles with Functionalism’, N. Block
    • Philosophy and the creation of computers

Notes

  • Notes 1
  • Notes 2

Videos

  • Required
    • One explanation of the Turing Test
    • Another explanation of the Turing Test
    • Necessary and Sufficient Conditions: Turing claims that passing the Turing Test is necessary and sufficient for intelligence. This video explains what necessary and sufficient conditions are.
    • A reconstruction of the Chinese Room Thought Experiment: This experiment challenges Turing’s claim that passing the Turing Test is sufficient for intelligence.
  • Optional
    • AI and Personhood
    • AI: Computers and Minds
    • The Imitation Game, a great movie about Turing. Available online on Amazon and elsewhere.
    • Her, a movie illustrating a highly advanced AI program. Available online at Amazon and elsewhere.
    • Star Trek: The Measure of a Man, a TV episode that touches on the issues for this week.
